Richard Sherriff

Description

Means of Play is an act of detournement that turns Salen and Zimmermans 2004 book Rules of Play from an artefact that helps us think about games into one that helps us play them.

Rules of Play is a foundational text for many of those beginning to think about games critically. It has introduced many designers to the world of games studies, and, conversely, many games researchers to the world of games design. You will find it on University shelves the world over, and (even if they did not read it) its striking cover and large size keep it in the mind of students long after they graduate.

Here, turned into a controller, it reminds us not to forget to take our head out of books and remember the potential virtues engendered by the act of play itself.

The current plan is to run Means of Play through a circuit-bent NES-on-a-chip (Famiclone) device to heighten an uncanny feeling during play that maintains an amount of critical distance between the player and the game, forcing them to consider the technology they are using to play.
